forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
I think the problem is that your computer is booting the UFD as a floppy drive. WinPE only works (looks for) HDD devices and so cannot find BCD on the 'hard drive'. Format the UFD using RMPrepUSB for FreeDos and copy the FreeDOS boot files to the UFD (kernel.sys and command.com). Now boot it - does it boot as A: or C: ??? If C: use the same settings and install Grub4DOS. If A: - reformat using different options in RMPrepUSB until it boots as C: (hdd)
I would try FAT32 first in this order HDD+2PTNS (which I think you tried and failed with) HDD 64/32 ZIP ZIP Force LBA
Also, look in your target system's BIOS for a USB boot setting like 'Boot USB drive as ' = 'Removable media' or 'Fixed Disk' and choose Fixed Disk option. Then try FAT16 (2GB size partition) Let us know your results.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> When I do geometry (hd0) I see:  
> Partition num: 0, active, Filesystem type is ntfs, partition type 0x07  
> Partition num: 1, Filesystem type is unknown, partition type 0x21

No, you don't. :smile:  

What you see is something like:  
> **drive 0x80 (LBA): C/H/S=1024/255/63, Sector Count/Size=16450560/512**   
> Partition num: 0, active, Filesystem type is ntfs, partition type 0x07  
> Partition num: 1, Filesystem type is unknown, partition type 0x21
You should be accurate when reporting, and more than that, you don't need to copy the whole set of Windows 7 files.  
All you need to do is to copy BOOTMGR and a /boot/BCD to the stick (with more than one entry), (or a NTLDR + a BOOT.INI with at least two choices) if you get to the choices, the booting went allright.  

The FreeDos message in this particular case seems to me allright, as you used a "wrong" geometry.  
0/1/1 means LBA 32 on a m/n/32 geometry which becomes 0/0/33 on a m/n/63 geometry as probably the USB stick "declares" itself.  

:smile:  
Wonko

Hi  
So you are saying that other UFDs work, but your original one doesn't??  

Did you try the ForceLBA option? from the TESTMBR results, it looks like BIOS is using CHS where it has 32 sectors per track (20). If you use ForceLBA it may work.  

When using TESTMBR in 236/237 then always use all of the file (not just one sector). Instructions have changed since v735.  

P.S. it is expected to stop with flashing cursor as you found. The code is just a test stub and will not actually boot to any OS.
